instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the proposed technique for the non-destructive determination of leaf nitrogen (N) concentration in pear orchards with mixed cultivars, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the proposed technique for the non-destructive determination of leaf nitrogen (N) concentration in pear orchards with mixed cultivars is the coefficient of determination (R-2) and the root mean relative error (RMSE). 

The R-2 value measures the proportion of the variance in the leaf nitrogen concentration that can be explained by the model. A higher R-2 value indicates a better fit of the model to the data. In the past study, the proposed technique achieved an R-2 value of 0.96 in the training dataset and 0.91 in the test dataset, indicating a strong correlation between the predicted and actual leaf nitrogen concentrations.

The RMSE measures the average difference between the predicted and actual leaf nitrogen concentrations. A lower RMSE value indicates a more accurate prediction. In the past study, the proposed technique achieved an RMSE value of 1.03 g kg(-1) in the training dataset and 1.29 g kg(-1) in the test dataset, suggesting a relatively small average difference between the predicted and actual leaf nitrogen concentrations.

Based on these metrics, the proposed technique shows high accuracy and robustness in estimating leaf nitrogen concentration in pear orchards with mixed cultivars.
